segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Okay. Well, thank you so much for having me today. I'm excited to speak here at ZeefCon.
Sorry I couldn't be there in person, but it looks like a lot of the conference attendees
are having a good time with my colleagues, George Orchias and Chris Peacock. So it's
been good to at least catch up and see some of those pictures on Twitter. Today, I'm going
to get to talk about one of probably the most fun things for me is talking a little bit
more about execution methods and diving deep onto the specific topic, because I think it's
something that's not quite visited enough when we're talking about some of our purple
teaming and how we're changing some of what we're doing as we test.
So a little bit about myself. I'm the adversary emulation lead at Scythe currently. I've been
here about a year and a half now. Prior to my time at Scythe, I did security research
at Sandia National Labs, did a little bit of everything. I also worked at MITRE, which
most people are familiar with because of MITRE ATT&CK. So I worked with that team, the ATT&CK
evaluations team, and that was really where getting into the sort of open source focus
of cyber threat intelligence, as well as tying that to adversary emulation and some of our
testing. So I've been around in this space for probably about a decade now and excited to at
least share some of what I've been doing over the past couple of years. So three big things
that I hope you'll take away from this talk is the first, of course, is why execution methods
are a hard problem. It's why they make security challenging, because they're sort of the ground
floor of everything else that we build things on. Second thing would be the mindset for how
you can do some tests and depth of testing with different execution methods. We often focus on
different types of techniques and working across MITRE ATT&CK matrix in this instance. And I really
want to focus on trying to drill down on a few specific ones and focus our testing there.
And then, of course, like a lot of talks, I want to make sure that there's a ton of resources for
you to work off of. So regardless of whether you're able to apply this in an enterprise
environment or you're a student or someone that's working from home or in your own lab environment,
that you still have a lot of different options to choose from when you're trying to learn more
about this topic. So what are execution methods? So I took this from
All right. Let's talk about execution methods. And just to give an example here,
let's talk about process discovery. So process discovery is T1057, for those of you that aren't
familiar with it. There's a bunch of different ways to execute it. And so if you've followed
me, you've seen some of this before, where there's tons of different ways to execute it.
We've got task list, get process. You can use other tools. And the difference between all of
these, even though they're all tying to the exact same technique, is the execution methods,
whether it's command line, PowerShell, WMI, or the Windows Native API. And so that's one of the
things that when I talk about variance and I talk about depth and execution methods,
it's about how we can change those and how, of course, those are going to impact our ability
to detect them. And this is how adversaries have been more and more moving towards changing what
they're doing. So why do they matter? One of the big things that execution methods give us
or give anyone is flexibility and expertise. This is across everything, whether it's legitimate use
cases, system administrators, operating systems are designed to have a wide number of use cases
and a wide number of users. So when we get to execution methods, just touching on some of the
ones we talked about previously, command line was obviously used first for systems administration,
things like that. We then, of course, have PowerShell. It's another big one that came
along. And so those are some of the ways that we're able to, that the operating systems are
able to sort of meet people where they're at and also provide new features while, of course,
especially in Windows, providing a lot of old legacy features so that people are able to continue
to leverage it. Telemetry inconsistencies. And this is sort of the heart of why execution methods
matter, is that getting information from each of them is a little bit different. And so being able
to write detections relies on that information. And of course, more and more adversaries or red team
research is done in order to try and find execution methods that don't have
any sort of telemetry or have low telemetry for defenders to work off of.
And so part of that is you have to determine the intent behind the action. Because these are
leveraging different technologies that are part of an operating system that are there for legitimate
use cases, we have people, you have to determine whether or not it is a typical program, just a
Windows application that's doing that specific behavior or whether it's an adversary trying to
abuse it in a blend in. And then that's where I've been talking about this and the sort of underlying
thing is that operating systems offer a ton of ways to execute different code. And you can
install even more, right? And you can continue to extend it. And that's something that I think is
sort of at the heart of the problem is that we have such a large attack surface when we're
talking about execution methods because there are more and more ways being invented
to execute code to meet developers and technology as it continues to grow.
Now, a quick roadmap of what we're covering today. We're going to go over a quick cycle
of execution methods as a whole, how they sort of build on top of each other. We're going to
go over a bunch of resources on sort of what you're going to need for testing and tools.
Then we're going to dive deep into Windows PowerShell and the different execution method
variants you can do in order to sort of thoroughly test it. And then we're going to talk a little bit
about the Lullabas project and MSBuild to sort of close it out. Now, the cycle of execution
methods. This is something that I picked PowerShell for sort of my main examples here and
partially because it's been sort of so well documented and a lot of people in this space have
a pretty good history of it. So, when we are talking about a life cycle, let's talk about how
something comes in to being an execution method. Part of it is its creation. And so, PowerShell
version 1 was released back in 2006. Now, something to remember, though, is that every
time something's released doesn't necessarily mean it's used. This was at a point in PowerShell's
life where you still had to download and install it and then it wasn't as widely adapted. And so,
that's something that comes into sort of the maturity of each of these different methods
is whether or not they're widely adopted. And so, when we look at PowerShell version 2 that
was released three years later, it was included in Windows 7 by default. Now, having default
installs is something that is going to increase your user base by a lot. And that's where we
have this intended use of PowerShell through system administrators that now have this tool
that was widely deployed by default that they could leverage. Now, of course, the next step
is what you can probably guess. The, you know, information security community always has this
part in it. And it's the unintended use of the execution method. And so, while these aren't
necessarily the pure points of where these things turned, right, it's a key thing to remember is
that research happens before publishing. And so, these things typically probably happened even
years before the actual talks. But there was a DerbyCon talk that went over PowerShell and was
like, oh, my gosh. And so, that was Dave Kennedy and Josh Kelly back in 2013. And then, of course,
Empire was one of the big first well-known command and control projects that sort of came out
and focused on some of those post-exploitation activities sort of opposed to Metasploit at the
time. And so, Cobalt Strike had obviously made some of those just C2 in general a big topic.
But PowerShell Empire was sort of the first one of the first ones that sort of came out that
was used widespread. Now, with that, of course, comes more and more people abusing these systems
in PowerShell. And that is where we get better logging and telemetry from the vendor, in this
case, Microsoft. And so, they had a lot of enhanced logging that they did in PowerShell version 3, 4,
and 5 through the Windows management framework. And really, the things here that you might be
familiar with are, of course, the script block logging. We're going to talk about that a lot,
like module logging. And then, of course, the constrained language mode and some of that.
So, that's really where we saw this sort of reaction from Microsoft in that case. They
released an entire blog post about how PowerShell loves the blue team too. And so, you can go check
and read through some of that. But the idea was to give defenders an ability to monitor and try
and lock down a lot of PowerShell's features. Now, the next thing is, of course, people look
for new execution methods, whether it's native API calls when doing that through different methods
like C sharp or some of the other red team research that you've probably seen. But the
idea behind this entire life cycle is that typically this is how people are going to go
through and look for things, especially when you're talking about adversaries are trying to
accomplish a lot of similar things. Even across time, their methods just change a little bit. And
that's really what it comes down to. So, this is a compounding problem because things keep
adding to it. We're covering you have to cover all the previous execution methods while also
tackling new ones that come out. And so, that's something that is challenging for any organization
because it means you need people that at least are plugged into some of those communities,
can understand what are some of the challenges. And, of course, this is while development is
still happening. PowerShell in this case is still a problem even all these years later because there
is active development. There are things that you can still use. And so, that's where you have to
have a team or a strategy for tackling some of those. And, of course, if your data changes,
whether you're swapping out EDRs or other defensive vendors, this is going to be something that
makes your challenge even harder is how do we make sure we maintain consistency in our detections
across all these execution methods while adding and taking away tools.
So, the purple perspective here is that it can be a good thing because execution methods tend to be
what we see and talk about when we're talking about adversary maturity. And so, this provides
defenders with a maturity map for how they can look at their own testing. So, you can use execution
methods as a way to see what level of maturity you're at. And so, from command line to PowerShell
to Windows API calls and there's a couple in between there, too, you can essentially track
how adversaries are building their own capabilities and then map that to your ability to not only
track but log and detect off of the behaviors being executed with those specific execution
methods. So, there is a positive here. Now, how do we solve all of this? This is, of course,
a Purple Team conference. So, through Purple Team testing. So, next we're going to talk about
different testing methods and tools. So, a little bit of advice here from somebody who's
been doing this for a little while is focus, especially if you're new to doing either Purple
Team exercises or to security testing in general, is to focus on one question at a time. Now, you
have to break your big questions into smaller ones and I've got an example here that we'll walk
through. But the big thing here is to pick a technique and you're not going to deviate from it
for this set of testing. If you're testing execution methods, you want to change one
variable at a time. The variable you're changing is the execution method and not the technique
itself. And so, discovery techniques are a really good starting point because they tend to have
something that you can execute on the endpoint. For instance, PowerShell, command line, WMI,
that kind of thing, it might have a one or two command execution where other techniques are
going to require a bit more effort. And so, for this one, our big question, and this might not
seem like a big question to all of you, is will process discovery T1057 generate an alert? So,
let's look at how we want to break this down. There's a couple different things we want to
focus on here. One is how do we execute the technique? We'll get into a little bit about
how this can get more complicated, but overall, part of the thing here is making sure that you
have the current skills and expertise to execute it. Now, for something like process discovery or
the other discovery techniques, they're a great way to start because they don't take a whole lot
here. Of course, you can execute it. In fact, a lot of them are used by programs, so that is even
going to allow you to execute it through potential protections and those new mechanisms that
Microsoft's put into PowerShell. The other thing, and this is going to be where it's going to take
some time, effort, and energy, is what artifacts are generated on the endpoint, in this case,
by what you're executing. In the course of process discovery, it'll depend on how we're
executing it, but this is where you need to at least be thinking of what are some of the things
that happen when I type in that command. Then, of course, what changes can you make that would
potentially impact that alert? Then, going over to what is probably a little bit more on the
detection side is where are you going to get your data? What's that data source you have for your
execution method? Of course, being able to correlate that with other data, this gets
more into that last point, which is analysis and how much you want to be able to do versus being
able to just see that you have the data that you're collecting. Depending on where you are in
your own testing maturity process, you might not be able to answer all these, and that's okay.
I just want to at least put these out there as this is a way that you can break down that big
question into smaller ones that you need to tackle individually. Now, our testing setup is going to
have three key components here, an environment, and, of course, using something like the cloud
is what a lot of testers are moving to, at least for standing up test beds, and I'll talk about
those a little bit in a minute. You, of course, need to collect data from that environment, and so
data collection tools, some of them can be built in, other ones are specific projects, and then,
of course, the last thing is our data generation, and that's really how these things break down.
We oftentimes think of it in red team tools or blue team tools or things like that, but at its
core, that's really what we're doing in an environment is we're trying to generate data
for us to work off of. Now, test environments, if you are working at an enterprise, it's ideal
for your production environment because you want all of that noise, you want all of those things in
play because you may find out that the execution method you're testing is used all across your
environment, and that is going to make it really difficult in order to write detections just
in a vacuum if you're in your own test bed. Now, if you're not, of course, able to do it in
your own production environment, there's a lot of other options, and these continue to grow, which is
actually great because it provides a lot of opportunities for more and more people
to learn about how enterprise networks work and how testing can work in them. So, virtual
machines, cyber ranges, that kind of thing, cloud providers, as I already went over, are sort of those
key components when you're looking at building different test environments. Now, I've got a
couple here that I'll talk to you. Attack range by Splunk, this has been a really popular one that's
continued to grow and be supported, and this sets up sort of everything for you. So, this sets up
your data collectors, this sets up your data generators, and, of course, gives you the
environment. It does require a combination of virtual machines and cloud infrastructure, so this
is one of those, you know, bring your own credit card in order to set some of this up, and that's
when we're talking about these cloud environments, a lot of times that is what you have to do.
You're setting up the environment in your own personal cloud account, so you can do testing,
but I would say watch out for that bill at the end of the month because there's a lot of stories
online of people that forget that they leave something up and then have a lot of money that
they have to spend. Game of Active Directory, this was also recently updated by Orange Cyber Defense,
they released version 2, and so this is an intentionally vulnerable Active Directory setup,
and the idea behind this is looking at the types of environments you want to test on and the types
of execution methods you want to test. Active Directory could be a key component to some of that,
so setting up some of these ranges allows for it. Detection Lab is another really popular one that
came out by Chris Long, and this is has, it's probably the most censored environment out of
everything here, and that's something that, of course, people have used if you are trying to
figure out exactly what artifacts get generated. Now, if you've never used it before, a word of
caution here is that if you start doing too many things at once, you're going to get a flood of data
and you're not going to know necessarily what to look for. So, again, keeping your testing small if
you're using Detection Lab for the first time is going to be key. Now, there's SnapLabs, which is
now part of Immersive Labs, also has Active Directory ranges. They have a Community Edition
where you, again, can plug in your own credentials and they will, they essentially have all these,
a lot of these things templated out, so you can just click Deploy and they'll, they'll host it on
your own infrastructure. So, it's kind of a cool way to set it up, and then the last thing here is
a book, and that's Building Virtual Machine Labs, a hands-on guide by Tony Robinson, and this walks
through if you've never built virtual machines before, you're just interested in learning more
about the depth that you can customize and how you can build some of these environments yourself,
that's a good starting point. Now, let's talk about data generators. These three questions are
the big things that I already talked to earlier, and the first, the first and last are going to be
your big things here, because how to execute the technique, just knowing how you're able to execute
it with that tool, as well as what changes and customizations can you make. It's not always
something you're going to be able to, there's, there's changes that might be limited because of
how the tool's built, so that's something that you've got to think of, or at least test out and
try out when you're going through your testing. Now, there's a bunch of different ones, I'll give
a shout out here to the C2 Matrix, that's sort of an aggregation of a ton of different projects.
SANS also released a Slingshot VM that's a C2 Matrix edition that has a bunch of those
command and controls automatically set up for you, because some of them do take builds,
and then you can just work from that, so sort of ease of deployment, that might be one way to do
it. Now, Atomic Red Team is probably the most well-known data generator, because it is probably
the most straightforward to use, although something to mention is, of course, if you're not,
if you're just using Atomic Red Team and sort of copy pasting off of that, or use, you may not
generate network traffic, which might be something that is, again, important to your detection for
your execution method. Caldera by Mitre, it's another big one, that's a personal project that
I really like, because I worked on it some while I was at Mitre, and it was sort of something I
really enjoyed. PurpleSharp, I think Mauricio talked earlier today, and maybe even highlighted
PurpleSharp some, so I'll give a shout out to him and to the project there, it's another one to check
out. And then to continue on with a book recommendation, there's Black Hat Python and
Black Hat Go by NoStarchPress, walk you through how to create a command and control framework with
either Python or Go, so that you're able to see exactly how things work, and you are essentially
writing some of the code that's going to do that data generation. So depending on what level you're
trying to learn, whether you're trying to just get something done quickly or build your own,
there's a whole bunch of options here, pick one or two and try them out, I think that's more
important than trying to pick the perfect one. Now data collection, again, we went over these,
and this is just to understand how are you going to be getting this data that you're testing in.
And so there's a couple of different things here, if you are in that production environment,
an EDR or other production tooling are going to give you a lot of data already. Now if you're
missing some, it might be as simple as turning on a feature instead of having to install something
completely new. And this is where I mentioned before that for lab environments, leveraging
a detection lab or attack range is something that will automatically instrument it for you.
So it has a bunch of sensors already, they also on the pages for the projects give you a list of
the different technologies, so that's something that you can of course leverage. Now if you're
building your own or if you're working in your own work environment, everyone talks about Sysmon,
and Sysmon is great, but a lot of organizations still haven't deployed it widely. So EDRs
essentially use similar collection methods to it, so it's a good way to at least get started.
And of course, these are the two major recommendations, Swift on Security and then
Olaf's modular Sysmon project are both really, really good places to start if you haven't used
Sysmon before. So and then the last thing I want to talk about here is of course network data.
This is something that a lot of what we're going to talk about and test on is the host, but network
data can become a key element when you are writing your detections in your environment. So this is
something that it's going to depend on what sort of insights you have, and this is going to be your
mileage may vary depending on your setup, but as you are maturing and learning more about this, if
you are building your own testbed, linking and correlating both the host-based information and
the network-based is going to be key. And so you have the Zeek project is one of those, formerly
bro, and then of course this is something I just like to talk about the data collectors because the
ELK stack is pretty popular, and so you have all the beats. So winlog beats is one of those
data collection methods. Now as far as when you start maturing and get to the point where you're
beyond data collection and you want to do some of that analysis, the key question here is what
data can you group together that sort of improves your analysis or might allow you to make a
detection that says this is for sure malicious or reduces the false positive rate that you have to
deal with. And so that's where you enrich the data that you already have, maybe it's a specific
process that executes and then is paired with network data so you understand at least what
is that host name or URL that it's calling out to. Those types of things can give you more
information than something that's sort of isolated and by itself. Now there's a couple of things here,
securityonion is a big one that's that is very popular, and then the ELK stack as I mentioned
before is something that has been built on a lot. And so I'll give a shout out to, you know, we've
seen the HELC, although I put the SANS ELK stack because it is more recently updated, and then I
want to give a shout out to Outflank for RedElk, which is sort of a red team view of the ELK stack
and sort of doing some of that offensive monitoring, which I think this was sort of the first
time that that came out, that a project came out publicly that talked about doing some more data
analysis for red teams, which I think is really good, so that's why I wanted to highlight that
specifically. Now alert generation, this is where things start to, there's not as many free resources
out there. EDRs have varying degrees out of the box, it just depends on the vendor and your setup,
but Sigma has become a massive project by Florian, and so that's something I just want to give a
shout out there, and so you can also port those Sigma rules to other formats, and he also has
built his own EDR that has a community edition, so that will tell you at least what Sigma rules
you triggered with some of your different testing. And then Elastic has actually released their
detection rules, and those are also widely available, so when we're talking about detections
for some of these different methods, we want to look at those. Now let's dive, let's start
diving into how you would test something like PowerShell, and PowerShell is still a problem,
as I mentioned, in 2022. The way we're going to execute it for this test and sort of talking
through it is with get process through Atomic Red Team test number three, and so I've got links
there at the bottom if you wanted to try and follow along, but the key thing here again is
now we know how we're executing it, following through all of those questions, looking at how
are we going to get information from that execution method. Well, we have Sysmon installed, so we have
Sysmon Event ID 1, so we're going to be spawning a new process, as well as having something like
script block logging, which might be overkill for this specific technique, but it's important
because of some of the things we're going to do a little bit later, and then looking at this,
sort of asking ourselves the question is what pieces are missing? Do we have process trees?
If this is something that this is the first time you're looking at it, process trees are going to
help you a ton because you're going to understand what artifacts are left on the system, and so
Process Explorer from the Sysinternals project by Windows is really good, and so this is one of
those things where, you know, opening and executing something from just a Windows GUI
might have Explorer as a parent process versus something that's not a beacon.exe, and so this
is where you'll see the differences between something like Atomic Red Team versus a C2
framework, and you should be able to test out those differences and at least spot a couple of key ones,
and something that people that are looking at this always ask, should we just disable
PowerShell? It seems like a problem, and I'm going to say probably not. Maybe you can in your
organization, but more and more people still continue to use PowerShell, and there's this
guide that was released on keeping PowerShell security measures to use and embrace in order
to make sure that it won't be abused, and so this was released by a joint set of governments,
I think all the five eyes. So let's talk about once you've executed that, we've maybe gotten
some detections, you know, are you done? And the answer, of course, is no. This is where we're
actually just getting started, and these are the key variations that you want to focus on
for execution methods, and you can probably come up with some other ones as well, but these are the
ones that have historically sort of been used by attackers or researchers in order to bypass
different techniques, and so some of the key questions we want to look at is, like, can we
run something without it being logged? Can we obfuscate what we run so that even if somebody
is able to collect it, they have to maybe do some analysis of their own to determine what
it even does? Can we copy and move it? Can we rename? And can we bring our own? There's a bunch
of different things here that you can test out, and really what this is is you're exploring the
features and capabilities of your execution method. That's really what it comes down to.
Some of them, like PowerShell, are pretty well documented because they've been around for a long
time now. I mean, PowerShell has been around since 2006, as we said, and so that versus maybe
the newer execution methods that might not be official even are going to be really poorly
documented, and so that might require a lot of research and discovery on your own or with a team,
and then this also is testing your assumption about how that method works, and as you'll see
with PowerShell, there's a lot of things that variations that essentially came out from people
testing their assumptions. Now, let's talk about running something without being logged. How do we
tackle this? Now, remember when I was going through our cycle here, PowerShell didn't start getting
really good or better logging and controls until versions 3, 4, and 5, which came out a bit later,
but PowerShell version 2 was installed by default for backwards compatibility up until I think last
year, and even now, a lot of different laptops or Windows machines that get shipped still have
version 2 enabled, and so this is something that you can do a downgrade attack, and this is where
you just tack on that you want version 2. You're going to run the same thing, and this is before
all of that logging happens, and so that's something that still happens in a lot of
environments, especially when we're doing purple teaming. We see this a lot. The other thing is
truncating logging. This is something that environments and especially if you're in an
enterprise that's trying to conserve the amount of data that they're storing, especially depending
on how you're storing it, maybe in the cloud versus on-prem, and so they might truncate to
the first 500 characters of something and figure that that's all they need,
and so in this case, you could just put and pre-pen 500 spaces before your test and see,
am I able to still see that? Now, this is where some things like script block logging might have
that minimized command that we'll talk about that get past this, but these are still a lot of
different good variations to prove whether or not those are working or not, and so that's really the
question to ask every time after you run one of these. Does my telemetry change? Does my detection
ability change or my alerting, which is really what we're trying to work towards?
Now, can we obfuscate what we run? Base64 encoding, this is something that's very much
inbuilt and part of PowerShell and is widely used for legitimate use cases too,
and encoding commands in general is something that a lot of especially automation and provisioning
tools use just to help make sure they're getting everything consistently across the network,
and this is why Base64 encoding is so popular also with adversaries, just because encoding
commands require at least one more step of analysis, whether it's just decoding it before
you try and understand whether it works, so you can check that and see whether or not you have
an analyst that's either going to, maybe the EDR does it for you, or maybe you have to pull
up CyberChef or something like that in order to decode the command to understand what it does.
Now, invoke obfuscation is another one of my favorite projects to talk about,
and that's by Daniel Bohannon, and this is where he sort of took to the extreme some of the
obfuscation techniques that you can do with programming language because you can insert
null characters and things like that, and the compiler or the interpreter will ignore them
because it's just trying to get at what is that thing you're trying to execute, but of course,
as humans looking at it, and this is an example where you can at least still tell what's going on,
you can see, all right, it's get process, but that might break some detections that are based
on just looking for a get process string. Other things, how about copy or moving the
PowerShell executable? We've been assuming that we're using the system path that's executing
PowerShell.exe, and so what if we copy and move it to just the user profile that you have and
execute the same thing? Is this going to break any policies or detections because people are looking
for that specific path of PowerShell.exe? And so, again, these are some of those variations
you have to think through, and especially when we start getting into other execution methods,
these can break a lot of what are sort of fragile detections in the area. Same with renaming.
This is something if people are looking for PowerShell.exe, maybe they decided that regardless
of where it's executed on the system, if you find PowerShell.exe, you need to detect on it,
and this is where rename, of course, is going to get past that. So, every environment and every
set of detections that have been implemented are probably going to be different. That's sort of
the reality. There's some people that can take all of Sigma rules, are part of Sigma rules in
addition to their own custom rules or what they have in the EDRs out of the box, but these are
what you're testing is all those assumptions about what works in environments. Now, let's
talk about unmanaged PowerShell, which is sort of works by, it was initially sort of coined by Lee
Christensen in 2014, had the unmanaged PowerShell project. PowerPick became in Cobalt Strikes,
so it was really easy to swap over. I think Empire also supports this. Of course, now it does,
but the idea with this is that typically your normal PowerShell execution, and this is sort
of a simplified version, was run through PowerShell.exe, and PowerShell would then
reference a DLL, and so the idea was let's just skip using that exe altogether and call the DLL
straight, and that's something that broke a lot of detections and still continues to break
detections, because people are focused on building detections around that PowerShell

that signed Microsoft Sign Binary status, and so that's where there's a project by Mr. Unicoder
that is called Windows Sign Binary that will tell you which bytes you can change in some of these
DLLs or other execution methods that are signed by Microsoft without affecting that specific
signature, so you'll still have a signed binary and it still works, but it won't have that hash,
so just ways that you can continue to sort of scale up what you're doing.
